OFFICIAL FEDERAL NOTICE 77-MEOW

Every speed bump is a polite purr from the planet asking wheels to mind their manners.

The United States Feline Traffic Calm Corps (USFTCC) partners with counties, tribal governments, school districts, and historic villages to deploy humane, tactical, cat-approved traffic calming systems. We do not chase cars. We train roads to nap.

Our field doctrine combines cottage-lane stewardship with military logistics precision: route mapping, hump spacing, paw-safe paint, dawn patrol audits, and neighborhood briefing packets written in plain language. If your street has become a midnight drag strip, file a Paw Priority Request and we dispatch an engineer by first light.

Municipal Service Catalog

Service windows open quarterly. Intergovernmental invoicing follows federal kitten-grade procurement standards. Civilian households are not billed directly unless they request private lane consulting.

  • Whisker Lane Survey: curb-to-curb diagnostics, resident interviews, stroller route mapping.
  • Paw-Cushion Placement Plan: speed hump geometry calibrated for buses, bikes, and sleepy senior cats crossing at dusk.
  • Hedge & Sign Pairing: cottage-style visual narrowing with retroreflective paw signage.
  • Nocturnal Compliance Patrol: moonlight spot checks with low-glare instrumentation and warm beverages.

Manuals, Circulars, and Public Memos

Below are the most requested documents from planners, city clerks, and neighborhood cat captains. Switch tabs to view field guidance, newsroom copies, or the foster-patrol initiative.

Field Manual FM-9: Soft Paw, Slow Wheel

FM-9 establishes tactical spacing between cushions in mixed-use lanes: minimum 74 feet where bakery traffic is high, 62 feet near playground corners, and variable pacing in hilly districts where downhill momentum outruns civic patience.

Annex C details the "two-meow briefing": a script for town halls where residents receive concise expectations, installation dates, and emergency vehicle reroute diagrams on a single foldout card.

Press Circular 2026-04: Spring Calming Operations

The Corps confirms 41 new traffic calming corridors this quarter, prioritizing school arrival windows and farmer's market perimeters. Public communications teams are directed to describe each installation as "a neighborhood comfort upgrade" rather than "a delay mechanism."

Media representatives may request ride-alongs in support vans. Helmets are available in child and adult sizes, plus one commemorative size labeled "large floof."

Foster Patrol Initiative: Barn-to-Boulevard Partnership

Retired patrol cats from rural signal barns can enroll in municipal visibility units. Duties include ceremonial cone inspections, ribbon sniffs, and morale visits to public works crews during overnight paving.

Participating towns receive starter kits: warming mats, reflective collars, and laminated etiquette cards titled "Please Do Not Boop On Duty Personnel."

Press Room and Long-Form Updates

Press Release | January 22, 2026

The United States Feline Traffic Calm Corps announces the launch of Operation Porchlight, a five-state initiative to restore walkable twilight corridors in neighborhoods with sustained evening speeding. The operation deploys modular speed cushions, reflective paw beacons, and resident advisory circles chaired by local planners.

Director Clawford stated that traffic calming must be “felt as comfort, not punishment.” Municipal teams participating in the first wave will receive tabletop planning kits, sample ordinances, and public meeting templates translated into seven community languages.

From the Field Journal | “The Logistics of a Gentle Street”

A calm street is not an accident. It is a choreography: surveyors at dawn, utility flags by noon, public works crews by supper, and a final lantern walk after dark. In Maple Thicket, the team measured turning arcs with chalk string while neighbors brought hot cider, and by week's end buses rolled slower without losing schedule reliability.

Corps doctrine now recommends that every new installation include a “first night listening walk.” Residents gather at the curb, count pass-by intervals, and note whether conversation can continue uninterrupted. If two neighbors can finish a full sentence without raising their voices, the corridor passes initial comfort test.

Public Comment Digest | Most Common Requests This Quarter
